title: Who will win the World Series?
possible_answers: A team from the National League
A team from the American League
correct_answer: A team from the American League
preds: Because the KC Royals won... Damn, I clicked the wrong league by accident.  Stupid me for trying to inflate my score...

To borrow a slogan from the '69 Mets: "Unbelievable". And "Unbelievable" in a different sense, as well.  The play that E. Hosmer made was a type of play that baseball has forgotten. Here is a description of the play (I lost the link):
"Salvador Perez hit a grounder to third that was fielded by Wright, who turned to freeze Hosmer at third. But when Wright threw, Hosmer broke for the plate, a move that was both risky and reckless. "The way they run the bases, you can't be shocked by anything,'' Wright said. "I'm sure that even Hosmer would say it was probably a bit reckless. But when you seem to kind of get the breaks and when you play the game that way, sometimes things like that work out for you." A good throw from Duda would have cut down Hosmer. A good throw would have sent the World Series back to Kansas City. A good throw would have allowed the Mets to escape their latest calamity. But Duda's throw sailed well to the right of catcher Travis d'Arnaud and went to the backstop. The Royals had tied it. A stunned Citi Field sat in silence. "You've got to tip your hat to Hosmer there. It took some [guts] to do what he did," Duda said. "It was an outstanding read and I didn't make the throw . . . like I said, no excuses. It's on me." ..... This is aggressive base running, demonstrating the type of decisions made, with "fast thinking", so unlike the "slow thinking" instilled in today's dull game by modern saber metrics.  
The type of play that Hosmer made, though rare in today's game is well documented in Ty Cobb's autobiography "My life in Baseball" Cobb played baseball in the first third of the 20th century. It is truly "unbelievable" that old style decision making has come back a century later to out do saber metrics. Congratulations for the excellent forecasting decision by Eric Hosmer in last night's baseball game!
The Fat Lady has sung. What a World Series!

This World Series is even more unbelievable than the last. Fourteen innings, who woulda thunk it? Where do these guys come up with such amazing plays, such preposterous errors? Is that guy still in hiding???? Bottom line: random errors happen. So far, Goddess Fortuna has favored the Royals. But I'm sticking with 5% chance for the Mets to pull off an upset. I swear, I'll rein in my amygdala tonight and hold to that 5% until the fat lady sings.

Up 2-0 in a 7-game series across NBA/NHL/MLB the historical result is about 80% leader wins the series, but is substantially lower for World Series for which it is only ~68%.  Interestingly, these odds change very little if the trailer wins game three (2-1), and if the teams then split the next two games (3-2).  If the leader goes up 3-0 or 3-1, however, the odds get very small for the trailer.  So... I'm going to predict that KC wins.  I don't see much reason to change that unless the Mets can tie the series at 2-2 at which point I'll have to re-evaluate.

Blue Jays had a 57% winning percentage and Mets had a 56% winning percentage, we can say they are close to evenly matched on a statistical basis, so we assume that each game is a 50/50 guess. Jays have won 2 games already, so we have 5 games left. We need the Jays to win 2 more times. Since the odds are the same as a coin flip, we ask how many combinations can we flip heads twice flipping 5 times, then we divide that number by the total possible coin flip combinations. The answer to the number of combinations is 2^5=32 total combinations and number of ways to flip at least two heads is 26 b/c math. So 26/32 is 81%. However, I add bias above this favoring Jays on momentum.
KC, the American League team, is up 2 games to 0.  Plus, they had a better overall record.

Assuming each remaining game is a coin flip (not a bad assumption at this point, given that each team has an equal number of home games), the Royals have a 66% chance of winning.  Betting markets suggest that the Royals have between around a 62%-63% chance of winning (see [1]).  I am going with an estimate at the upper range of the betting market range. [1] http://www.oddschecker.com/baseball/mlb/world-series/winner

These two teams are very similar.  NYM have better starting pitching, KC has a deeper & better bullpen.  Their batting quality is very similar, but KC has more speed on the bases.  Their defensive quality is very similar.  Also, both teams are used to playing in close, low-scoring games.
The 2 things that tip the scales in KC's favor are its home-field advantage & the Playoff experience they gained from playing in last years World Series.

It's either Cubs or Mets for the NL. Looking at the stats, those teams are so closely matched they're almost clones of each other. No clue who will win there. Vegas odds are calling for Jays to win the AL matchup. It's a grudge match though, so who knows. Home team advantage goes to AL. That hasn't been as much of a factor as expected this post-season, but it's historically an important statistic. IMHO this looks like Jays vs Cubs. If you look at the matchup (link below), the Cubs have a slight advantage in pitching, but the Jays have a huge advantage in hitting and a slight advantage in defense. The pitching would be a big deal if this was a best of 5, but this is best of 7, so we'll see everything both teams have got. Again, just my opinion, but the run differential is going to count more over 7 games. Wildcards: we still need to see who the final matchup will be, and if it's the Jays for the AL, we need to see *which* version of the Jays will actually show up (i.e. the respectable but average .500 team, or the invincible, thundering bats of doom). http://www.sportingcharts.com/mlb/teams/matchup/238-toronto-blue-jays-2015-vs-240-chicago-cubs-2015/#Win%20Percentage$SeasonMax=9999&SeasonMin=1990

The American League has home field advantage again this year, which provides an advantage for those teams (American League) that have a bona fide designated hitter on their roster. Despite the Giants win in 2014, home field advantage for the American League does have real consequences. All the above provides a reasonable pretext for my belief that the Royals will win this year.

• Previous stats (WS home team winning pct. in DH era, WS home team winning pct. since home field determined by all-star winner)
• ELO (http://fivethirtyeight.com/datalab/best-2015-mlb-teams-blue-jays-elo/) picks Toronto (19%) 
• ELO suggests that the wildcard teams in the NL are better than the division winners, but, of course, one of them will be gone, tonight
• PredictWise (http://www.predictwise.com/node/4031) ranks Toronto and Kansas City 1, 2, and says their combined win probability (37%) is equal to the next three teams (all NL). Translation:  Good probability that AL strength makes it through, and best AL teams are better than best NL teams, which have a lower probability of making it through (and then there's the home field stat, which looks lobsided).

Just a gut feeling...lol..no scientific basis for my forecast....

Apples vs Oranges (if the little league team in your town won 90% of their games would you pick them to win the world series? -- after all, they have a higher winning percentage than any of the teams in the MLB playoffs.  Of course not! ... why?.......It's a case of apples and oranges... they did not play the same competition. What's that got to do with the real World Series? Total Interleague Play:
 .....AL 167-133 winning pct. 55.7%
......NL  133-167 winning pct. 44.3% 10 of 15 AL teams (66.7%) finished with winning records vs the NL (11 wins or more of the 20 games).
4    of 15 NL teams (26.7%) finished with winning records vs the AL. Interleague Comparison of the 5 AL and 5 NL Playoff teams (end of season): 
AL - Hou +12, KC +6, Tor +4, NYY +2, TX +2    AL Total +26
NL - Pit +6, StL +2, LAD 0, ChC  0, NYM -2       NL Total + 6 Clearly, the AL is the superior league (based on an old statistic called "wins").
Why do some NL teams have better winning percentages?  Look at the NL East division: they finished at 374-446, or 72 games under .500.  The NL East was 38-62, or 38% against the AL, and 336-384, or 46.7% against the NL.  Again clearly the AL is demonstrated to be the superior league.  But, notice that each NL East team only plays 20 games against the AL while they play 142 games against the NL. Had the AL played 142 against this type of NL competition the AL win totals would have been far higher.  Another side note: as of last weekend (a week ago), only 1 AL team had been eliminated from a chance at the playoffs (a very balanced competitive league), while in the NL, 9 teams had been eliminated (it seems to be a very mediocre, unbalance league). Wonder why Las Vegas doesn't mention any of this?  I'll give the NL a 33%, based on the old baseball truism...  everyone wins a third of their games. http://espn.go.com/mlb/standings/grid
Toronto is the best team in baseball.  They have outscored their opponents by +221 runs.  St. Louis is second in the league at +122, almost 100 runs worse.
Only because I am a diehard Cardinals fan!

Very difficult to predict, so low confidence. First point is that the Cardinals have the best record in baseball. However, a better predictive factor is run differential, where the Blue Jays dominate, scoring 221 more runs than their opponents, compared with 122 for the second-place Cardinals: http://www.sportingcharts.com/mlb/stats/team-run-differential/2015/. That leads to an expected 103 wins, compared with 93 actual wins this season. Suggestion is that the Jays have underperformed so far thanks to luck. Also, Jays have added David Price, one of the best pitchers in baseball, for their postseason run; strong starting pitching is crucial for the postseason. Either the Blue Jays, or a team that gets hot enough to beat the Blue Jays, will win the Series.

In the American League the Jays and Yankees are both the expected contenders with win %s of .572 and .553 respectively. In central it is the Royals with .586, the potential Twins at .513 and in the west it is Texas with .546 and Houston as a potential wildcard with .523. The Angels are still possible with .513 as well. For making the world series, the AL favorites are Blue Jays and Royals, followed by Rangers, Yankees, and Astros. Texas will likely play the Jays, with Jays a heavy favorite. Astros and Yankees will pace off in the wildcard with New York the favorite and that winner will play the Royals.  The eventual teams in the world series will most likely be the Jays, Royals, or Rangers in order. In the National League, The Cardinals are strong favorites with a .638 pct, Dodgers at .572, and Mets at .562. The wildcard will likely be Cubs and Pirates at .582 and .610 respectively. The teams most likely to be in the world series for the NL are Dodgers, Cardinals, and Mets respectively. In terms of winning the world series, the AL has won more of the interleague contests this year at .548%. The American league also won the all star game and has home field advantage which can be a slight boost. I would give a slight edge to NL with their records, but it is by no means sure at this point.

According to Vegas ([1]) , American League teams have a 52% chance of winning the World Series, while National League teams have a 48% chance (AL win chance = (sum of implied probabilities for AL teams)/(sum of all implied probabilities).  I didn't include teams with odds of greater than 100 to 1).  According to Fangraphs [2], AL teams have a 49% chance of winning.  Both sources suggest a 50% estimate would be appropriate.  I'll go a shade above 50 because the AL will have home team advantage and has done better in inter-league matches. This question is very much unlike most GJP questions in that there is very little Knightian uncertainty [3] involved.  Any reasonable mathematical model (e.g. Fangraphs) will tell you that the odds are about 50-50.  In addition, there are well-developed betting markets that also suggest 50% odds.   Baseball is a very random game; even if the AL team will (on average) be very slightly better than the NL team, 7 games is simply not enough time for quality to overcome randomness.  An answer of 70% (for either side) is simply unreasonable; it is like predicting that a fair coin will land on heads with 70% probability.  I find it a bit disturbing that the GJP consensus is so obviously wrong.  Ideally, the GJP should be about reducing Knightian uncertainty, and it is hard to believe it can creditably do that if it can't get it right on questions like this. [1] http://www.vegasinsider.com/mlb/odds/futures/
[2] http://www.fangraphs.com/coolstandings.aspx?type=2&lg=lg&date=current
[3] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knightian_uncertainty

When I first got the email that this question was gonna be asked (a couple of days ago, not sure why we got emails before the question went live, I was VERY worried that they were going to ask us which TEAM we thought would win the WS). As a fan of the Blue Jays (I remember the early 90s!), I didn't think I'd be able to answer the question without bias. Luckily, it's simply an AL/NL question, which still presents a bit of a problem, but not nearly as much as if we were trying to pick the winner out of 8 to 10 teams. I realize that I could probably write WAY too much in a rationale for this, so I'll be as brief as I can, while still adding value to the discussion.  One thing to consider when it comes to forecasting sports (in my experience) and in particular, baseball, is that there are innumerate statistics or perspectives that one could adopt. Predictably, one would unconsciously gravitate towards those that support preexisting beliefs.  ~
With that being said, I think that FanGraphs offers the best "data-backed" solution when it comes to predicting who'll win the WS. Here's a link (updates daily) with the percentages for each team's chance of winning the WS (along with playoffs percentages, etc.): http://www.fangraphs.com/coolstandings.aspx?type=2&lg=lg&date=current Unsurprisingly, if you add up the percentages in the AL and the percentages in the NL, they both amount to about 50%. Aside from that, the one thing that stands out is the % for the Dodgers. For those who follow baseball, this will make sense given the make-up of the Dodgers' pitching staff.  If I were really taking my time with this question, I'd game out who the Dodgers are likely to play in the NLDS (the Mets?) and look at the matchup between the two teams and then game that out against the Cardinals (who'll *probably* beat the NL WC team). In the AL, it's looking like it'll be the Royals who'll play one of the Yankees or the Rangers (i.e. the AL WC team), who'll then  likely play the Jays (who appear like they'll be playing the Astros).  From the baseball I've seen this year, I have a sneaky suspicion that the Dodgers won't make it past the NLCS (if they even get there!) and I really think the Jays can beat all the teams in the AL in a 7-game series. To this end, I think the only team that I'd bet on against the Jays in the WS is the Dodgers (because of the starting pitchers). ~ Alright, so that was probably a bit rambling in parts, but I tried to cut down on tangents. In short, I'm slightly favouring the AL -- for now. My prediction now is based on who I expect to make the playoffs in the AL (Royals, Jays, Yankees), who I think have a better chance of winning than the (Cardinals, Cubs, Mets).
